oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Perspectives of Small Retailers in the Organic Market: Customer Satisfaction and Customer Enthusiasm
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bolten, Jan
Kennerknecht, Raphael
Spiller, Achim
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Markets and trade
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Abstract. In this paper we discuss the impact of customer satisfaction and enthusiasm on the performance of small retailers in the organic food market. The analysis of customer satisfaction and shop data confirm essential economic effects. The study is based on 948 customer interviews and an analysis of management ratios of 12 organic food shops in Germany. The results show that customer satisfaction is a relevant key to sales performance. Regression analysis reveals that overall customer satisfaction accounts for 32 % of sales per square meter sales area. An additional factor analysis identifies service and product quality as main determinants of customer satisfaction. Consumers consider the freshness of fruit and vegetables as representative for the quality of the whole assortment. A correlation analysis demonstrates that customer enthusiasm is a more accurate factor in the recommendation of shops than customer satisfaction. The paper ends with managerial and scientific implications.
